rsbNotes.title: Pr 5
rsbNotes.text: 5:1–23 This passage is best taken as a single unit. While vv. 15–23 are conceivably a distinct composition, the theme is a logical development of what goes before. Wisdom urges us to avoid the life-destroying adulteress and to find sexual and emotional satisfaction in faithfulness to the marriage bond.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 5:7–14
rsbNotes.text: 5:7–14 These verses provide a more detailed description of the fruit of immorality and the price it exacts.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 5:8
rsbNotes.text: 5:8 Keep . . . far from her. The wise will make a conscious choice to avoid any contact with immorality and keep out of the way of temptation.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 5:9–11
rsbNotes.text: 5:9–11 Those who foolishly engage in immorality pay a high price for it.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 5:9
rsbNotes.text: 5:9 the merciless. Perhaps the outraged husband of the adulteress (6:34, 35).

rsbNotes.title: Pr 5:10
rsbNotes.text: 5:10 This verse may refer literally to the high cost of keeping a mistress (a “foreigner”). Or the warning may be that immorality takes away wealth and strength.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 5:11
rsbNotes.text: 5:11 Such dissipation leads to regret as one reflects on the waste and futility of the life that has been lived.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 5:12–13
rsbNotes.text: 5:12, 13 Sexual immorality epitomizes the way of folly that rejects the discipline of wise instruction.

rsbNotes.title: Pr 5:14
rsbNotes.text: 5:14 congregation. In view here is either public disgrace or punishment by the covenant community.
